Award.AwardTitle: ACTPol: The Atacama Cosmology Telescope with Polarization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) is a project to investigate the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) at high angular resolution that was constructed and operated under NSF support over 2005-2010. The ACT facility - a 6m off-axis Gregorian telescope, detectors, and infrastructure - has had two successful seasons of science observations during 2008 and 2009. The awarded project is a follow-on program, called ACTPol, to greatly increase the number and sensitivity of the detectors, and to add linear polarization capability. ACTPol will upgrade and extend instrumentation on the existing telescope, which is located on Cerro Toco (17,030') above the ALMA site on the Chajnator Plateau in Northern Chile. It will address important questions in both basic physics and astrophysics, and if successful will perform transformative research. The program will run for five years. A new bolometer camera with polarization sensitivity will be constructed and used with the ACT for the following science goals: 1) Constrain the initial conditions of universe and measure "running" of scalar spectral index with k; 2) Measure spatial curvature of the universe and dark energy; 3) Discover or constrain the sum of the neutrino masses; 4) Measure the amount of primordial helium; 5) Determine the growth rate of structure; 6) Complement the Planck satellite on smaller angular scales; and 7) Enable future large-scale B-mode polarization measurements.

ACTPol will continue to pursue the types of broader impacts already successfully undertaken by the ACT project. These include a commitment to training students and postdoctoral researchers, continuing strong international partnerships, exchange of technology and personnel with NIST, and outreach to teachers and middle school students, among other activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award was the principal funding source for the operation and upgrade to the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) in northern Chile. ACT’s purpose is to measure in unprecedented detail the cosmic microwave background (CMB), the three degree thermal afterglow of the Big Bang. Through measuring spatial variations in temperature and polarization at the level of a millionth of one degree centigrade we have discovered new clusters of galaxies, measured for the first time effects that are rapidly becoming standard cosmological tools, constrained the mass sum of elusive elementary particles called neutrinos, searched for new elementary particles, confirmed in new ways and to new levels the standard cosmological model, and have found phenomena that will help us understand the process of the formation of cosmic structure such as galaxies and clusters of galaxies. The results are published in over thirty papers.

The science was made possible through the invention of new technologies and algorithms. For example, the collaboration has developed arrays of thousands of mm-wave detectors that operate at 1/10 of a degree above absolute zero. The detectors are coupled to the sky with novel optics, including a new type of silicon meta-material.The data analysis is done on super computers in Canada, South Africa, and the US.  The science results are all the more remarkable when one considers that the data are taken with a 6 meter telescope at a self-sufficient remote site at 17,000 ft altitude. The telescope is continuously monitored by collaborators at their home institutes.

Training the next generation is at the heart of the project. The science is done by a collaboration of roughly seventy-five extraordinary scientists from over twenty universities and research labs distributed across six countries. The expertise covers topics ranging from state-of-the-art detectors, to new computational algorithms, to theory. Over 50 undergraduates got their start with ACT and a number are coauthors on our papers. Graduate students and postdocs of the project have gone on to industry, federal labs, and academic positions.
